text.p: These are the leading stories in the Belgrade press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified them and does not vouch for their accuracy.
POLITIKA
- Yugoslav President Zoran Lilic and Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe discuss in Harare promotion of bilateral relations and Yugoslavia's return to the international community.
- Greek Foreign Minister Theodoros Pangalos expects soon a unified European space including the Balkans.
- A group of 45 Krajina Serbs, to be released from Croatian prisons under the new Croatian law on amnesty, due to arrive in Yugoslavia on Thursday.
- A group of 53 refugees to return to Croatia Thursday in the sixth transfer organized by the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees.
- Serbian Deputy Prime minister Slobodan Babic and Industry Minister Oskar Fodor to participate in conference of the Danube basin countries in Austria.
- The Priboj car factory FAP and Germany's Mercedes Benz are expected to renew cooperation by the end after four and a half years of sanctions.
- Former Yugoslav central bank governor Dragoslav Avramovic offically withdraws as head of the opposition list Zajedno.
- The Banja Luka airport in northern Bosnia technically ready for traffic, says British Overseas Development Agency which has invested 200,000 sterling in its reconstruction.
NASA BORBA
- Privatisation process in Montenegro in full swing and cannot be stopped, says director of the development fund and economics professor Bozo Mihajlovic.

- The Serbian commodity reserves directorate will finance sowing of only 300,000 hectares through barter and commercial bills, leaving 500,000 hectares to be financed by the farmers themselves, says director of Jugoagrar Bozidar Djelovic.
- Import quotas for mineral fertilizers will not be increased by the end of the year, the Yugoslav chamber of commerce industry committee said.
- Serbian-Albanian round table on Kosovo issue to be held from December 18 to 22 in New York, says vice-president of the Democratic League of Kosovo Fehmi Agani.
POLITIKA EKSPRES
- Belgrade public transport company to buy 100 buses from Germany's Mercedes, and inter-city service Lasta 50 Hungarian Rabe buses. Buses to be completed by Yugoslav Ikarbus company.
VECERNJE NOVOSTI

- Yugoslav side in talks on succession of former Yugoslavia says not only state property on the territory of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, but also Croatia, Slovenia, Macedonia and Bosnia subject to division.
- The banking system cannot be rehabilitated unless means is found to repay more than $4 billion owed to old hard currency depositors, says Investbanka deputy general manager.
-- Belgrade newsroom, +381 11 222 4305
